summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting permission to install secure high-speed wired Internet access in the courtroom for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial, followed by the judge's signed order granting the request. The trial is set to begin on November 29, 2021.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the Ghislaine Maxwell case who receives the government's request and signs the order permitting secure Internet access in the courtroom for the trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is set to stand trial beginning November 29, 2021.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submits the request to the court on behalf of the government.

connections.description: Williams, as U.S. Attorney, leads the prosecution team against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Start of Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
events.description: The trial proceedings for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell are set to begin.

locations: United States Courthouse, New York, New York
keyFacts: The U.S. Government requested and received court approval to install a secure, high-speed wired Internet connection in the courtroom for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial to facilitate evidence presentation.
The trial in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330) was scheduled to begin on Monday, November 29, 2021.
The vendor Courtroom Connect was authorized to provide the Internet service, ensuring the network was separate from the court's internal systems for security.
Judge Alison J. Nathan signed the order permitting the arrangement in November 2021.
